name: Fosterheald
swornTo: Paramount Driht of House Wilfrey, Drihten of House Wilfrey of Breakmount
notes:
The key leadership role for the Wilfrey fostering system. A role of high status within the wider Wilfrey houses and beyond. The Fosterheald serves as the supreme authority over House Wilfrey's fostering tradition - a role of profound cultural significance second only to the Breakmount Mine Master in institutional importance. This appointed position carries responsibility for shaping the character, loyalties, and capabilities of every noble child entrusted to Wilfrey care.
The Fosterheald determines curriculum, approves all staff appointments within the fostering system, mediates disputes between fosterlings, and maintains relationships with the families who have placed children in Wilfrey wardship. They hold the authority to discipline, recommend early release from fostering, or in extreme cases, petition for a fosterling's dismissal.
Traditionally, successful Fosterhealds have been drawn from former fosterlings themselves - individuals who experienced the system firsthand and emerged exemplifying Wilfrey values.

name: Fostermarshall
notes:
The Fostermarshall bears responsibility for the martial education of all fosterlings under Wilfrey care. This encompasses instruction in mounted and unmounted combat, tournament preparation, tactical thinking, and the physical conditioning expected of nobility.
Beyond mere weapons proficiency, the Fostermarshall instills discipline, courage, and the warrior's code of conduct that fosterlings will carry into adulthood. They assess each fosterling's aptitudes and limitations, tailoring training accordingly while maintaining baseline standards all must meet.
The Fostermarshall coordinates closely with the Fosterbookman to ensure academic and martial schedules complement rather than conflict, and with the Fostersteward regarding equipment provisioning and training yard upkeep.

name: Fosterbookman
notes:
The Fosterbookman directs all academic instruction within the fostering system - a role requiring both scholarly depth and pedagogical skill. Core curriculum includes literacy, numeracy, history, heraldry, law, and the administrative knowledge expected of future lords and ladies.
Beyond standard education, the Fosterbookman identifies individual talents and interests, arranging specialist instruction where warranted. A fosterling showing aptitude for cartography, medicine, or theological study might receive additional tutoring at the Fosterbookman's discretion.
The role also encompasses maintenance of teaching materials, correspondence with outside scholars, and careful record-keeping of each fosterling's academic progress - documents which follow them throughout life.

name: Fostersteward
notes:
The Fostersteward ensures the practical machinery of the fostering system runs smoothly - a role encompassing housing assignments, meal provision, clothing, medical care, and the countless daily necessities fosterlings require.
This position demands diplomatic skill alongside administrative competence. The Fostersteward must balance the expectations of noble-born children accustomed to varying standards of living, manage the personal servants fosterlings bring from home, and maintain household harmony among young people from potentially rival families.
The Fostersteward also coordinates ceremonial occasions - feast days, arrival and departure ceremonies, and the formal events that mark a fosterling's progression through the system.

name: Fosterreeve
notes:
The Fosterreeve manages all financial matters pertaining to the fostering system - a responsibility requiring both numerical precision and diplomatic discretion. Noble families pay varying amounts for their children's wardship, and the details of these arrangements remain strictly confidential.
Income streams under the Fosterreeve's management include fostering fees, equipment contributions, and occasional gifts from grateful families. Expenditures encompass staff wages, provisions, training equipment, educational materials, clothing allowances, and the countless incidental costs of maintaining noble youth in appropriate comfort.
The Fosterreeve maintains meticulous accounts separate from Breakmount's general ledgers, presenting regular reports to the Fosterheald and annual summaries to Lord Wilfrey. This financial independence ensures the fostering system remains self-sustaining and shields it from competing budgetary pressures within the wider household.
A skilled Fosterreeve anticipates needs before they become urgent - ensuring funds exist for replacing worn training equipment, expanding library holdings, or accommodating an unexpected influx of new fosterlings.

name: Fosterwarden
notes:
The Fosterwarden holds dual responsibility as both security chief and deputy to the Fosterheald - a combination reflecting the role's origins in protecting valuable noble hostages during less peaceful times. In the Fosterheald's absence, the Fosterwarden assumes full authority over the fostering system.
Security duties encompass the physical safety of all fosterlings, staff, and visitors within fostering quarters. The Fosterwarden commands dedicated watchmen, controls access to sensitive areas, and coordinates with Breakmount's broader garrison during emergencies. When fosterlings venture beyond castle walls for training exercises or excursions, the Fosterwarden arranges appropriate escort.
Disciplinary authority represents the role's other major function. Minor infractions fall to individual staff members, but serious misconduct - fighting between fosterlings, theft, attempted escape, or behaviour bringing dishonour - comes before the Fosterwarden for investigation and judgment. They hold authority to confine fosterlings to quarters, assign punitive duties, or recommend more severe consequences to the Fosterheald.
The combination of security and discipline creates a figure fosterlings regard with healthy respect. A wise Fosterwarden balances firmness with fairness, understanding that today's wayward youth may become tomorrow's powerful ally.

name: Fostertallyman
notes:
The Fostertallyman serves as the Fosterreeve's primary assistant in all matters of accounting - a position demanding meticulous attention to detail and absolute trustworthiness. Every transaction flowing through the fostering system passes through the Fostertallyman's ledgers.
Daily duties include recording expenditures, reconciling accounts, tracking inventory consumption, and maintaining the endless paperwork that financial management requires. The Fostertallyman ensures receipts are collected, payments documented, and discrepancies investigated before they compound.
Beyond mere record-keeping, an experienced Fostertallyman identifies patterns - noticing when equipment costs rise unusually, when certain suppliers offer poor value, or when consumption suggests waste or pilferage. These observations, reported to the Fosterreeve, enable proactive management.
The role serves as traditional training ground for those aspiring to reeve positions elsewhere. Many estates have welcomed Fostertallyman alumni into senior financial roles, their Wilfrey training considered mark of competence.

name: Fosterhirdward
notes:
The Fosterhirdward manages the complex web of personal servants accompanying fosterlings from their home households - a role requiring equal measures of authority and tact. These attendants owe primary loyalty to their young masters and home houses, yet must operate within the fostering system's rules.
Coordination challenges abound. Personal servants may clash with fostering staff over proper procedures. Attendants from rival houses might carry family grudges into their daily interactions. Some fosterlings arrive with extensive retinues while others bring minimal staff, creating awkward disparities. The Fosterhirdward navigates all of this.
Practical responsibilities include housing assignments for attendants, establishing clear boundaries of authority, mediating disputes, and ensuring personal servants support rather than undermine the fostering system's educational goals. An attendant who helps their young lord evade training or smuggles forbidden items answers to the Fosterhirdward.
The role also monitors attendant welfare - these servants, often young themselves, are far from home serving masters who are themselves still children. A thoughtful Fosterhirdward recognises their vulnerability.

name: Fosterhorseward
notes:
The Fosterhorseward bears responsibility for transforming noble children into confident riders - a fundamental skill expected of any wellborn adult. This encompasses basic horsemanship for newcomers, advanced riding for the competent, and mounted combat training for those approaching the end of their fostering.
Beyond instruction, the Fosterhorseward manages the horses dedicated to fostering use. Training mounts require particular temperaments - patient enough for beginners yet responsive enough to teach proper technique. The Fosterhorseward selects, maintains, and eventually retires these animals, always ensuring appropriate mounts exist for fosterlings of varying ages and abilities.
Coordination with Breakmount's main stables is essential but carefully boundaried. Fostering horses occupy dedicated stalls, and while farriers and veterinary care may be shared resources, the Fosterhorseward maintains independent authority over training schedules and horse assignments. Fosterlings who bring personal mounts from home present additional complexity - these animals must be evaluated, stabled appropriately, and integrated into training without disrupting established routines.
The Fosterhorseward also teaches horse care directly. Noble youth must understand grooming, feeding, tack maintenance, and the signs of illness or injury. A lord who cannot assess their own mount's condition is a lord poorly prepared for campaign or crisis.

name: Fosteredgemaster
notes:
Oversees: Blade instruction, armoury management, equipment supply and maintenance
The Fosteredgemaster holds dual responsibility for weapons instruction and the physical tools of martial training - a combination recognising that excellence in blade work requires excellence in blade care. One cannot teach the sword without understanding the sword.
Instructional duties focus on edged weapons of all varieties. Longsword forms the foundation, but fosterlings receive exposure to shortswords, daggers, and polearms as appropriate to their age and aptitude. The Fosteredgemaster assesses each student's natural inclinations - some favour power, others speed, others precision - and shapes training accordingly while ensuring all meet baseline competency.
Armoury management represents equally vital responsibility. The Fosteredgemaster maintains the fostering system's dedicated store of training weapons, practice armour, and protective equipment. This includes wooden wasters for beginners, blunted steel for intermediate students, and properly weighted sparring weapons for advanced training. Every item requires regular inspection - a cracked waster or loose rivet invites injury.
Supply duties extend to coordinating with Breakmount's smiths and external suppliers. The Fosteredgemaster specifies requirements, evaluates quality, negotiates costs with the Fosterreeve's approval, and maintains inventory records. When fosterlings outgrow equipment or training demands expand, the Fosteredgemaster anticipates needs and requisitions accordingly.
A well-run armoury reflects its master. The Fosteredgemaster who tolerates rust, disorder, or ill-maintained equipment fails not only in duty but in the example set for students. Weapon care is weapon respect, and weapon respect underpins martial discipline.
